commentBody:
Nice fill, good theme, slightly on the easy side.

8/10
Dat's Brilliant!
OK, Isaac. Did you forget to change the lead photo in the column, or did Deb steal this one from today to use yesterday?

A very easy puzzle, with an unexciting theme of three actors and a singer (which feels like an outlier) whose initials are D.B., with nothing more in common, and no revealer like "Harry (or Hairy) Styles" to bring them together.  By a constructor whose initials are also D.B., which makes it seem a little self-indulgent.

When DELTA BURKE went in, I thought maybe it was a Greek letter theme. But there's no Greek letter called DANNY.

But at least George liked it a lot.
Will this be an Easy Tuesday after a Hard Monday, or just an Average Tuesday that feels Easy after a Hard Monday?
Yules to you too. Not a fan of this at all.

So for this 60-ish year old the names were all gimmes, but there’s multiple generations who will be saying Huh? Partridge Family? Designing Women? And isn’t Drew Barrymore a talk show host? And David Bowie was a movie star?
Still I don’t like to dissuade debut constructors—congratulations, this was a solid grid, and keep expanding your horizons!

Who thought the changes to the stats pages were a good idea?  The results distribution is now un-usable.  The whole point is to be able to compare today’s time to the average and best times for the given day of the week.

Please reconsider.

I enjoyed it. Easy but entertaining. Quite the ROMP. 

The revealer made me groan, but in a good way.
May it be a comfort to younger solvers that if you’re old enough to remember these shows you’re also old enough to have completely forgotten them.
Cute theme. But can someone be a conspirator if they only conspire with themself?
I thought this was a fairly ho-hum theme until I reached the revealer, which made me laugh out loud. A clever Tuesday.

Pretty easy, and only a couple of spots where I had to wait on crosses, The names came quickly, but then, I've been around for a while. I've always liked Jim Henson's work, one of which was Labyrinth, and DAVID BOWIE was appropriately EVIL as the Goblin King. And IMDB is one of my favorite tools on the web, as I'm not much of a movie watcher.

Nice debut, DB, and Thanks!
Aw, I appreciated the callout to Lars and the Real Girl. That movie is bizarre but shows so many acts of kindness that it ends up being heartwarming.

So good to see Alma given a fresh clue rather than Mahler's wife or mater's mate. Loved the lyricism of thin auric layer for gilding. Auric, what a great word. The MASS clue seemed a bit of a stretch but I got what was going on, variations on state abbreviations, but since there's a wealth of other ways to clue MASS I wondered why this clue? 

IMDB very cute. I knew it had to do with D-B but that didn't click. Sweet little surprise there at the end. 

I just came from reading some sports articles on The Athletic. In the comments the regulars insult each other and hurl curse words about with abandon -- and not much monitoring. It's pathetic. Not amusing in the least. Yet here, among people who love words and their magic, we are over-monitored to an extraordinary degree -- the emus are techy and the human editors nearly as intolerant. But the Athletic and Games are subscription services, but we are held to different standards. In the regular Times, some columns and articles have comments, not others. There's no guessing why. Some comments get delayed for hours before they appear, without any explanation, or never appear, especially if they are critical of the author's postulates. Others, like the ever-present "Socrates" get put up right away. It's all so cockeyed. Kind of funny isn't it?

Congratulations on your NYT debut, DB!  An enjoyable puzzle after a stressful day.  Lucky me, I’m old enough to remember the TV shows, movies and the RUBADUB nursery rhyme.  IMDB sounding out to “I am DB” was pretty clever.  Looking forward to your next one!

I would say that this a stately, no baloney puzzle, one with graceful clues that do not hand you the stars on a platter, but do make it possible to fill them in confidently from the crosses. 

I loved this puzzle, and I was impressed by the fresh cluing of the glue that held it together.  This may be a debut for the NY Times, but Mr Britt clearly knows his chops.

Thank you, Daniel.  I think this is the beginning of a beautiful friendship.
Great debut, DB!
Congratulations on your New York Times puzzle debut, Mr. Britt! Here's my Diary of a Crossword Fiend write-up: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/07/14/tuesday-july-15-2025/#ny
The reveal was neat. But I must say I’m a bit annoyed that David Bowie had to share this grid with Danny Bonaduce.

Congrats, DB! I found this very enjoyable.

I’ll be surprised if there aren’t a bunch of complaints about the long names, especially from overseas solvers who probably don’t know the Partridge Family from Duck Dynasty, but fortunately for me I knew them all. And I thought the revealer was cute.

I’m also wondering why don’t see more instances of EIEIO. Seems like a constructor’s dream.

I got a nice little smile at the very end, as the names lit up and I entered the last answer, finally seeing the theme come together.  Well done.  I typically solve without any attention to the theme if I can help it.  A really good theme will make itself invaluable in solving.  But another fun kind of theme leaves you alone but then reveals itself with a sly twist at the end.  This was the latter kind.  Cool debut.
Nice Debut, D.B.!    Hope to see more from you!
I thought this was a little tougher than the usual Tuesday, but all the more satisfying for it. Nice debut!

To those who are encouraging Daniel Britt to keep trying and someday he will become a real crossword constructor, read the column and read his notes.  He's been constructing for years and publishing puzzles for the past eight years in an "alt monthly."  This Blowout Game may be a debut for the NY Times, but it was clear to me that he knows how to construct a solid puzzle. This one is a Tuesday, and is at a Tuesday level, but we don't often get such classy Tuesday puzzles.

Thanking him would be more appropriate.
Ahh!  Finally trivia I know!  A fun Tuesday puzzle for me!  Thank you and I hope we see more DB!

The crossing of DANNY B_NADUC_ and F_RE and _IEIO was impossible for me. Unknown name of an actor from a show I've never seen crossing an expression from a sport I know and care nothing about (I thought it would be FiRE, maybe), and some nonsense letter salad (is that from Old MacDonald had a farm? I've never thought how one would spell that bit). Yaaaay. I had to look up the name of the actor.

I owe not being stumped by RUBADUB (which also crossed the actor's name...) to mishearing Rick's of Rick & Morty catchorase. To quote R&M Wiki: 

"Wubba Lubba dub-dub" is Rick's iconic catchphrase, frequently used in Season 1, and initially seems to be an expression of Rick's happiness or humor. However, as Birdperson later explains, in the Bird People's native language, it translates to: "I am in great pain, please help me." 

I generally found this puzzle tedious. Not what I needed today to cheer me up. Wubba Lubba dub-dub.
Bloop? Bloopers I know. Never heard the term “bloop” in baseball. YMMV.
NYT crossword comments accurately reveal who you'd want to sit next to on an overseas flight.

THAT was clever. Enjoyed discovering the twist! 
I appreciated a bit more trivia in my generation of knowledge. Kudos!

Knowing this comment section, I'm sure it's already come up, but in case it hasn't:

The new design for the stats area of the iPhone app is nice. But honestly, one of the best bits about the old version was the ability to see average/best/current scores side-by-side, which provided a quick visual way to compare the current week's times to the average. Not only are they no longer side-by-side, but the interface changes the scale for each chart, so I can't even hold the length of one chart in my memory and switch to the other, because the scale changes. It looks slick, but it makes the information far less useful. I hope they consider adjusting it so that the aesthetics don't undermine the usefulness.
Fun puzzle. I didn’t realize they were your own initials until the end. Clever.

Very easy until the SE corner. What the heck is greenhorn? House of (blank)? Shakespearean conspirator? “Later”!? A basic cable show winning an Emmy for drama? I had no knowledge of the constellation resembling the instrument or the word for “dry as the Sonoran desert.”

So weird. My whole grid was filled except that section which was wicked hard. I wish those clues were spread out better bc that seems to all be very specific knowledge. At least for me (age 47). 

I did get IMDB though. Cute reveal. Love the double meaning there!

Congratulation on your crossword, and many more to come.
I didn't know any of the names except IAGO and AVON but I accept that, as a non-US solver, it happens.

Another Shakespeare link - I've always remembered SERE from Macbeth, where old age is 
"The sere and yellow leaf."

NUDIEBAR - A club where men drink in the nude? Amazing.

I view a Tuesday puzzle as being a breeze but having a few clues that remain unanswered until I get more info from the rest of the board.  This one had more than a few that I had to wait on.  Felt more like a Friday (or at least a Wednesday)
Welcome and congrats, DB.
Cool! I've been saying trivia is the same thing as a Natick, so we get a puzzle that's almost all celebrity trivia. Thanks, I guess....

I wish we could go back to the original statistics chart. The new ones are not as visually useful, require more keystrokes and make it harder to compare the week’s scores to historical ones. Please offer the option for the Classic Coke version.

What?  Here's a DB puzzle and we haven't yet had a Do Better comment?






Et tu emu.

What a great debut. I loved it.
Didn’t know all the names and of course the sporting term was behind me, but the crossings were kind.
Chuckled at SMUT crossing NUDIE BAR.

Fun fact. I tried to get into the cinema to see The Man Who Fell To Earth, as I was a huge Bowie fan,  but was ejected despite a face full of make up and my most grown up outfit. I think I was 15 and the film was rated 18 here. Given that I looked younger than my age it was a fools errand. I had to carry ID with me well into my 20’s to be sure of getting served in a pub (legal age 18 UK).

Congrats on your debut, Daniel Britt! Well done. 

Finally, there’s trivia that I know, understand, and have experienced. 

Happy Tuesday!

Congrats on the debut DB and I liked your opening line that this is your *first* NYT published: now that's optimism.  

Deliberately ignored the revealer clue so had a nice chuckle when that filled in. 

Have a neighbor with the same initials and the car's vanity plate is IMDB.

I've just experienced an example of why its important to check things before making a complaint about a supposed mistake in a clue. I was already to say that it is Stratford-UPON-Avon but have found out that even though that is the name of the town, the local government district it is in is Stratford-ON-Avon. So my nitpick falls.
Very clever and smooth, nicely polished! Wonderful debut, Herr DB!
I was imagining While I was solving This trio singing (And that's a good thing!): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VSBOa7C0O7c&list=RDVSBOa7C0O7c&start_radio=1 (witty banter until 1:18)

Weird crossword coincidence: 

After finishing his puzzle, I started the 9/17/08 puzzle, which has a movie title theme. At least one theme clue was gimme: [David Bowie: The Man Who ________” (1976)”].

A nice puzzle. Great revealer! But as a huge fan of the Austin, Texas band Spoon, I can’t not comment on the constructor’s name, which is the reverse of their lead singer, Daniel Britt. So, two appropriate songs: “Written in Reverse” https://youtu.be/mAOt1VXHFtE?si=SODGveYTwWkWZYQ2 “I Ain’t the One” https://youtu.be/FjDj9JMpAP4?si=VbPjYllpBykf80P7

I loved the sing-song answers KABUKI, EIEIO, NOGO, BLOOPS, RUBADUB, ABU, and maybe throw in IAGO.  

Was happy to have a long answer – DANNY BONADUCE – that I never heard of, to titillate my brain’s workout ethic.  DANNY I could infer, but BONADUCE was all crosses.

I love the backstory of how Daniel came up with this theme, a joke nascent in his head for a quarter century turned into a crossword.  And how he persisted through multiple iterations to improve it.  

I liked seeing many answers that sound like other words: CIAO, SARI, KNEAD, GILD, DRE.

And of course, I loved the “Hah!” that came out of me when I uncovered IMDB.

Thus, much feel-good permeating the box today, a sweet gift.  Thank you for this, Daniel, and WTG on your Times debut!

Fun puzzle and a good workout for me. With my memory, I of course didn't remember any of the theme answers immediately but managed to work them out from the crosses. Just lots of nice 'aha' moments. Looking forward to more from Mr. Britt. I expect he will become a familiar name here. And of course a cute puzzle find today. Don't even remember how I stumbled across this one. Anyway - a Thursday from November 24, 1977 by Tap Osborn. Four 15 letter theme answers, all clued as parts of a verse: FROMBANGORMAINE PASTALBUQUERQUE THANKSGIVINGDAY WEALLTALKTURKEY Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=11/24/1977&g=25&d=A I'm done. ...
As a local.. I wondering if 29D should read "Stratford-UPon-___"...
Well done!
Thanks to having a boomer mother, I got the Partridge and Designing Women clues immediately. Weird how what’s easy for some can be tough for others.
Great debut puzzle. The accompanying photo funny but the headline in the newspaper creepy.

Think it would have been a hoot had DANIELBRITT been one of the thematic entries, with a cryptic clue like "It's his big day!" Congrats, D.B., on your debut.

Very solid puzzle. I wonder if DELTABURKE and DANNYBONADUCE were a bit obscure to the younger folks here? In any case, these two entries seemed largely free of troublesome crosses---though I did have IRES instead of IRKS until I realized BUREE had to be BURKE.

Fun Tuesday puzzle.

I am under 35 and found this puzzle impossible. I hope some of the older solvers had fun today, but I had absolutely no idea any of the celebrities and ended up just googling for answers. David Bowie is the only one I have even heard of.
i dont think proper name themed puzzles are very fair
As it happened, the first DB I came to was the Partridge Family, and it struck me funny that it rolled right out. Yes - there it is, taking up space in my brain!
I don’t know if this is good or bad, but DANNYBONADUCE was a gimme for me.
What a wonderful Tuesday! Congratulations on your debut, DB. This one was fun. Thanks!
67A 'Shakespearean conspirator', is incorrect: a conspiracy requires two or more participants and IAGO is a solo act.
Not being a fan of sitcoms, ever, I disliked this puzzle. Television clues are ruining everything for me, even Jeopardy.

I love the revealer! So clever! Lots of interesting fill. I got stuck on 38A. I kept wanting to write “rout.” But once I saw that 30D had to be NAMED I was temporarily stumped. For 39D, I kept thinking of chicken instead of fruit or vegetables. Ugh! I got it in the end, without lookups, but about a minute slower than my average solving time. Fantastic Debut, DB!

Fun romp down memory lane for me . I watched the Partridge Family as a young teen and loved Shirley Jones. I wanted to grow up and be a cool Mom like her . Also loved Designing Women and of course ET .  Thanks for the memories DB and a clean solve as well.
I’m ok with TV trivia as long as the clues around the answer are not TV trivia as well. Puzzle had nice flow and was solvable without lookups.

A fairly breezy Tuesday, largely in my wheelhouse. I know some are complaining about the actor names but there are many days when I’m at sea since I know next-to-nothing about music post, say, 1990, have no interest in superhero action movies, and don’t watch much TV. For example, I saw one episode of Game of Thrones, decided it wasn’t for me, so I’m lost when it comes to any clues arising from it…but that’s life in the CW. Put me down as as saying kudos to DB, the constructor. BTW, this could be just me, but the appearance of MAD MEN and KABUKI puts me in mind of one of the best scenes from the series: https://youtu.be/5y4b-DEkIps?si=mPiXP65X-ojpnDSp Lastly, add me to the list of those who prefer the former means of displaying stats.

I have only one complaint - the trivia cross of the Partridge Family and golf makes me feel like I may as well be from SATURN, I simply had to guess there. (I also didn't know DELTA BURKE, but crossings happily got me there.) But the theme is so charming that I can't be mad. It's always nice to see some truly original wordplay!

Those salon hairdryers of yesteryear must be reeeally slow… two days straight and those ladies’ hair still isn't dry?

The “remove skin from” kind of gave me the heebie jeebies. Thank goodness it referred to fruit, I was thinking too much along the lines of the Criminal Minds series. (Apologies for the darkness).

As a kid, I was fascinated by the movie Bridge on… Sir Alec Guinness was one of the all-time great actors, as are so many of the English. William Holden did a phenomenal supporting role and the whole story is great.

Romp and pans, I don't use either in the way they're clued and I seldom hear them used, but now I know. 

I almost never hear or use the term nudie bar, except if I were Al Bundy. I would use the more popular term strip club. That is, just in a passing conversation, nothing more. Honest. I swear. SMUT, is what it is.

The new oil, ain't that the truth. Keep rejecting those cookies, people. That's all I care to say about that subject. We all have our idiosyncrasies, this is one of mine.

Debates over whether dogs go to heaven when they pass, it's of little consequence. Any member of the animal kingdom that brings us such joy, yet so much sorrow upon their passing, may just be a glimpse into heaven. I'm with you, @Andzrej!

Congrats to DB on his debut! It was a fun one. With fill like KABUKI, RUB-A-DUB, and NUDIE BAR, what's not to love?

On a side note, the NYT recently published an article about the longevity of It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia, so while solving this puzzle, all I could think of was Dumpster Baby.
Any puzzle with DAVID BOWIE is okay by me. And in honor of the recent 40th anniversary of Live Aid, here's his performance of Heroes from that day. https://youtu.be/dsnTZHQZzN4?si=myvpFVCcWNYZbDO2
Great puzzle DB . So fun to see trivia from my generation . I loved the Partridge family- and wanted to be Shirley Jones when I grew up. Also loved Designing Women . Thanks for a fun Tuesday solve.
Ya done good Daniel – fun puzzle!

TATA and DATA are both candidates for "new oil." I had the T in GILT (instead of GILD) already there, so I had to read this column to solve the puzzle. I might have lost my mind trying to figure out my mistake. 
I should slow down a bit.

Gen X: Monday
Millennial: Tuesday
Boomer: Wednesday
Gen Z: basically a Thursday 😂

One time I was at a slumber party, I think we were all 8 or 9. And of course, up all night, freezing up underwear and having seances. In the morning, to wake us up for breakfast, the mom put on the Colonel Bogey March, super, super loud. It was memorable. If you like the Partridge Family, they were based on the Cowsills, and there is a really compelling biography on them called Family Band. It is on Amazon and is worth watching.  Very fun puzzle too.

Thanks for a very enjoyable puzzle with a fun theme, Daniel Britt. 
I got all of the actors and singers on my own, with some help from crosses to assist my memory. The last to fall was DELTA BURKE, as I’d never seen that series. 
I don’t have time to read other comments right now. Have to get out for my morning walk before it gets way too hot. But I am scratching my head because in my app, the Wordplay photo for today’s puzzle is the same one that was used for yesterday’s puzzle. Sorry if it’s already been discussed. 
Everybody stay safe out there please.
What an enjoyable Tuesday offering! Just enough crunch ...and for some, a fun traipse down memory lane... Grazie, Daniel!

Let my comments through!!!!!!

Please.
Loved it, very clever theme!

Oh, behave!


DR E
      V
       I
       L

Helen Reddy, are you ready for this:

Delta Burke, wearing flowers and a smirk
Could it be you like a twerk to quirky rhymes?
And did I hear some jerk he was a-wondrin' how to work
Your name into a crossword in the Times?

(I know Helen Reddy didn't write this or sing it first, but she am woman who had the most success with it.)

(I hope it's clear I used "jerk" solely because it rhymes. I meant no insult to a fine new constructor!)
Congratulations to Daniel Britt, for a fun and well constructed puzzle, and for his determination to keep refining it. I enjoyed it!

Nice puzz. 15A reminded me of the always apt Gil Scott-Heron spoken word “Work for Peace.” The military and the monetary Get together whenever they think it’s necessary They turn our brothers and sisters into mercenaries They are turning the planet into a cemetary Use the media as intermediaries They are determined to keep the citizens secondary https://youtu.be/IgZDDW-NXDE

Loved this puzzle. Very clever to be able to work all those DB names in!
Thanks and keep ‘em coming.  

Everyone have a nice day!
Not a great puzzle for a 25 year old that doesn't own a television LOL
Great puzzle today!
The answer to 7D depends on whether "coat" is a noun or verb.
I have S_UT for 17A and I have no idea what the missing letter is to make it porn.  Am I too pure for this world?

In honor of beloved pets we've lost, am changing my avatar to Fergus.  

(Formerly "Jim Nc", now "Jim Carrboro NC")
I just changed my avatar and my location, but apparently the emus grabbed it.
this puzzle was nearly impossible for anyone under 35

As a TV watcher of many years, who habitually runs through all the Acrosses before starting on the Downs, I was thrown off by the fact that Annie Potts also has ten letters!  I had to get both D.Bonaduce and D.Bowie to realize there was a theme and go back.

Hi folks, just a quick note for those who like unique and unusual puzzles. 3 February 2015 is both, and a Tuesday to boot. 

Keep the faith, and play the archives when the news is too much!

I got a real boost from this one when I read the clue for "Designing Women".  

I've never seen the show, as it came out in a period in which I watched virtually no TV.  But I do remember talking about it with someone once, and she was listing off the actors.  Only one of them caught my attention:  Delta Burke.  

I don't know why she stuck in my mind, but she did, and I thought when I saw the puzzle "Geez, the only one I know is Delta Burke."

So I was on my way to getting my streak up to a big two.  (That's a numerical value "2".

Took me 25 mins (way over average!!)….I am also under 30 years old. No complaints! My issue was with GILD/DATA….I mistakenly had OTToWA for far too long and that threw me off! Spent 10 minutes trying to figure out my mistake.

He's ba-a-a-a-a-ck!!  After lurking for a couple of years to focus on more positive things when Wordplay seemed to take on a mean tone, I was encouraged by our Central North Carolina WordPlay meet up lunch today at the O Henry grill in Greensboro! Jim, Maggie, CatPet, Liz, Becky, Leapy, David, and I were there swapping travel stories and fav's about puzzle solving.  I brought people up to date of my 18 months of chemo (so far) and how I kept my streak alive while waiting in OR for surgery for a broken hip.  The nurses thought I was nuts!

today's rabbit hole: ROut vs ROMP.

Maybe I'll de-lurk more now.

Positive vibes to all!!!

one of the life sciences is "ecol"? Seriously?

- signed an academic life scientist
beautiful puzzle bravo!

To @B of NY (confession: I’m not sure if there are more than one of “you” - one B who lobbies for a puzzle of the decade, and one who doesn’t and to whom this is replying): Back on July 11 you shared a link to the Washington Post’s “Hard Puzzles”: https://www.nytimes.com/shared/comment/48qeqq?rsrc=cshare&smid=url-share I’ve now attempted six of them (July 10-15), and on average I found them much harder than the current ones at this location. I completed three “cleanly (including today July15, which I found the easiest), completed two with a couple words revealed in each, and gave up on Monday July 14, which I found too brutal by far. Different cluing than at NYT - a little touch of cryptic, and clearly a different editorial style. I’m glad I tried it. Not having a subscription made the interface irritating (ads). But I feel a slight temptation to continue…

This was such a fun theme and I liked how it tied to the author’s name. Congrats on the debut! 

My trivia skills aren’t as sharp as my word play skills, so it took me longer to solve than my average Tuesday time. But it’s always good to improve the knowledge base.

Bravo, well done Daniel. A nice mix of old and new clues, and I loved the IMDB. I wonder how many people know that it also stands for Internet Move Database- A great resource for movies, tv shows, and in addition, full of bio's on just about any actor or actress you want to look up! (IMDb.com)

I don't know if any of you are Tom Lehrer fans, and I don't know if any of you are aware that Tom has put his entire catalog of songs, both published and unpublished, in the public domain and has made them all available for listening and/or downloading (unfortunately one at a time, it appears) from a site called TomLehrerSongs.com. There is a long disclaimer statement, and then the songs are listed in alphabetical order. Sheet music is included on the page. One of his songs concerns one of our answers in today's puzzle, and his take might be slightly objectionable and is certainly dated (from the 1960s), but I'm posting its page anyway. No video, just a couple of versions from different albums. https://tomlehrersongs.com/smut

@Barry Ancona
I think Deb borrowed it. The picture goes with today's headline.
@Barry Ancona It's going to be a blow out week so the same blow dry photo every day.  :-)
But I am not fond of the newspaper headline in the photo given the recent event in Texas.

@Steve L
Isn't IMDB the revealer?
@Steve L Since David Bowie has been in movies, he is also an actor. So not really an outlier.
@Steve L You can get to the stats by tapping on Me -> The Crossword, but then you have to select average, this week, or best individually, so I prefer Isabeau‘s method. Thanks, Isabeau.
@Steve Oops, posted to the wrong spot. Sorry.
@Steve IMDB was a cute revealer…

@Steve L

Did you have a bad day?
But now I'm wondering, if there was so much fuss about "hairy" not sounding like "Harry" yesterday, what about "IM" not sounding like "I am"?

@The X-Phile

That makes sense.

Steve,

Moving has made for a rough week for you. 
Hope you'll get settled in soon.

@Steve L
What you meant seemed clear to me.

@Barry Ancona
Many will hate it because of all the trivia.
SIGH.

@Barry Ancona

Sigh right back atcha.

@Barry Ancona
"I know we've only known each other four weeks and three days, but to me it seems like nine weeks and five days. The first day seemed like a week and the second day seemed like five days. And the third day seemed like a week again and the fourth day seemed like eight days. And the fifth day you went to see your mother and that seemed just like a day, and then you came back and later on the sixth day, in the evening, when we saw each other, that started seeming like two days, so in the evening it seemed like two days spilling over into the next day and that started seeming like four days, so at the end of the sixth day on into the seventh day, it seemed like a total of five days. And the sixth day seemed like a week and a half. I have it written down, but I can show it to you tomorrow if you want to see it."

OMG! 
Today was Average for early solvers 
but by now it is Hard!

🌎  Global Stats
Difficulty
Hard
Median Solve Time
7:48
Median Solver
3% slower
⚡48% of users solved faster than their Tuesday average.
14% solved much faster (>20%) than their Tuesday average.
🐢52% of users solved slower than their Tuesday average.
25% solved much slower (>20%) than their Tuesday average.

@Hanson

I had to use AI to find the reference (I actually never saw “The Jerk”) but now I have to watch it. I love Steve Martin. Again I have to recommend “Only Murders in the Building”.

@SP

I’ll give you designing women, but I’m barely 30 and the rest of those were gimmes for me! ET is a classic, and labyrinth is a cult classic. Partridge Family is probably more unknown for a lot of people, but I know it from boomer parents and also from That 70s Show.

@SP yeah don’t want to be that person but this was not fun for me. Well at least I got DAVID BOWIE and DREW BARRYMORE without looking up but the other two, I had no clue and it made this a slog even after figuring out the theme.

@SP
I’m not a fan of movie clues.  But, the theme was so cute I forgive the (rookie) constructor.

@Richard Williams Email the editors. Crosswordeditors@nytimes.com I looked at mine and it has the wrong name and wrong start date, but all the stats seem correct. As an android app user on a phone before this I had no easy access to my stats.

@Richard Williams You can still go here for stats: https://www.nytimes.com/puzzles/stats I also have an android phone and have this site bookmarked. The new stats on the app seem okay, but I like to see the date of the fastest time so I still check the bookmark.

@Richard Williams
I solve on the NYT Games app on my iPad and my stat page hasn’t changed. This is the 2nd comment I’ve seen since last week on the issue. Am I missing something or maybe you’re solving on a different app? Just curious.

@Richard Williams (Correcting my earlier post in an incorrect thread .)  You can get to the stats by tapping on Me -> The Crossword, but then you have to select average, this week, or best individually, so I prefer Cathy‘s method. Thanks, Cathy.
@Valerie The stats page has changed for me and, like you, I’m solving via the NYT Games app on an iPad. Is your app up-to-date?
@Cindy  Yes.  Last updated July 9th and I see no new updates in the App Store. Weird. In other news, my granddaughter is moving to your city this week. Hope she likes it!

@Valerie

Even though i had downloaded the latest app earlier, I did not see the stats changes people were noting here until I force re-started the app, which then apparently picked up the new version with the modified stats layout. The new layout looks to me like a (misguided?) attempt to bring a kind of standardization to the stats display across all the games.
@Richard Williams my biggest stat problem is that one day got wrongly recorded as way shorter than it actually took me, so I have an unreasonable and unbeatable personal "best" time saved.

@Richard Williams
It’s a classic case of form over function.

@Richard Williams

It looks to me like another change in the latest iOS version is that the app is now integrated with the iOS “Game Center”. I believe this is true because I am getting a Game Center welcome popup when I open the app. I had never seen this before.

@pacer9

Me too! I kept getting that popup that looked familiar but I couldn’t remember where I’d seen it before. Now I remember it was from the Games Center that used to pop up when I played Words with Friends.

@Valerie That’s odd about the app. I hope your granddaughter likes it here, too! Each neighborhood has its own personality but there is teriyaki everywhere.  If she loves books, she can ask for a library passport at any Seattle Public Library and tour them, getting her passport stamped at each. There are 27 of them in the passport.  It’s a good way to get to know neighborhoods and maybe catch a bite to eat nearby. The passports actually came out over 15 years ago so some libraries may no longer have copies to distribute, but I think it shouldn’t be too difficult.

@Cindy
Her mother is Japanese and came to the US back in the 80’s to go to college in Seattle before moving to LA.  She taught my granddaughter how to cook Japanese food and told her there are a lot of Asian markets in Seattle so she’s looking forward to that. I’ll tell her to look into the library passports. She would love that. Thanks for the info!

@Cindy 

You're welcome, and thank you for the Seattle Library info. The passport sounds fun, and I just read that you can get free museum passes with your library card.

@Cindy
I'm also  on iPad App, and my stats page still looks the same as always.

@Gina D

Speak for yourself!!

@Gina D
Ah, to be 75 years old and a rap fan:  That is truly the best of all possible crossworlds.

@Wayne C
My thought exactly!  

By the way, the Stratford Festival in — naturally — Stratford, Ontario, has been an extraordinary place to see Shakespearean plays, and a whole lot of other live productions for that matter, for more than 70 years.  This season, I am especially looking forward to seeing Robert LePage’s directorial take on Macbeth.  It is, strangely, placed in the 1990s Quebec biker gang wars period. (Such directorial vanity sometimes flops for me but I saw Robert LePage’s production of Coriolanus several years ago, placed in the internet era, and it was superb.)

If you have never experienced Stratford, Ontario’s theatre before, I urge you to try it out.  Come for a week and have the time of your life.

@Rachel That movie is so lovely that just reading the title gives me a jolt of endorphins. Was talking with some friends the other day about feel-good movies. I came up with Paterson and The King of Hearts. I can’t believe I forgot about this one.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Al you are a font of knowledge. Stay away from the CMU area tomorrow. You Know Who is gonna be there...

@john ezra
I, too, dislike the over-monitoring almost as much as I dislike the bias, but people will be people, and we pay a subscription fee for this “privilege.”
As an occasional poster on this blog, I enjoy the more civil of discussions, but it only takes one boorish comment to sway this crowd of intellects into a downward spiral. Shouldn't it be the opposite?  
The optimist side of me believes the delay in the eventual release of comments from the NYT filtration system is tied to how busy the platform is at premium times of the day. It's quite possible that same platform that Wordplay engages is parsing through all NYT articles, and just chugs along. When it's too bogged down, it simply discards. I think maybe Socrates, Hepicurus, Archemedies, and even Mephistopheles hits it at just the right time of day or night(?)
@Jamie Egad!  ;)

@Heidi David Bowie is British.
I thought this puzzle good. The crossings gettable so long names gettable.

@Heidi There were two theme clues where I hadn't heard of the individuals. However, the crossers were all solvable for native English speakers. (Acknowledging here, Andrzej's more unusual circumstances,) I did end up looking up those names in the Wordplay, but that was due to my not having thought through the crossers properly. It's when two rare proper nouns cross that naticks occur.

@Heidi

EIEIO has been an answer in 74 puzzles, almost all of those in the Shortz era. 

Oh.. and just a side note - HEIDI has been an answer in 62 puzzles. 

....

@Ian Hookham

As an American I didn't know his last name until much later when he started making "trouble" of various kinds as an adult.  He's been living in a kind of semi-celebrity radio host / reality show provocateur / criminal space for a long time.

@Lauren

Of course the entire world should know David Bowie! My comment was directed mainly at Mr. Bonaduce, who I thought would be known only to US residents of a certain age. Glad to know mediocre American television transcends international boundaries!  (Or am I? Hmm.)
@Salvo as always, my complaint is with the editors, not the constructors. This puzzle is great, but belongs in People, not NYT.

@dutchiris

Huh, I didn't really see the negative ones.  I thought this was about perfect for a Tuesday and a really pleasant solving experience.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

@dutchiris

Good point. I hope my personal comment did not seem too condescending. To be honest though I thought the puzzle lacked the panache of a more experienced constructor—even for a Tuesday. But I’ll try to pay more attention to the constructor’s background in the future.
As usual, I'm special. I checked the comments to see I was the second person today who didn't like the grid. Wubba Lubba dub-dub.

@Francis

My best friend died in my arms. I felt him stop breathing. Forever. His pain is over, and there was no other way to end it, but so is our life together, of fun and adventure, of smiles and tail wagging, of so many big and little things... 

I only today realized how big a part of me he was, and how empty everything feels now... 

We burried him in my dad's garden, in a meadow of wildflowers, with all his plushies. It was beautiful but so terribly sad. 

I don't know what to do with myself. I've never so desperately wanted to believe in an afterlife as I do now.
@Francis @Andrzej Sending you both strength and healing. I am so sorry for your losses.

@Andrzej

Do we really need to hear once again that you found a puzzle tedious because you didn't get some of the American cultural references?  I find it amazing that you attempt a crossword puzzle from a foreign country at all, but also tiresome that you need to tell us about things you wouldn't be expected to know.

@Jim

You chose to write this today, of all days. Good on you. I'm sure you feel great about yourself. And the scary and sad thing is, you probably do. You waited for the perfect day to reply nastily to me, and today was it. You did this to grieving man with suicidal thoughts.

@Andrzej @Francis

My heart goes out to both of you.

@Andrzej I must have missed an earlier post, I’m assuming you lost your dear Jorge. My heart goes out to you. I know I’m just one of many here who truly understand and have felt your deep sorrow. I’m so sorry.

@Andrzej
Please explain. I don't know what you talking about.

@Andrzej

I was responding to your post which did not indicate anything about a loss.  I was unaware of any loss you may have suffered and would never have never piled on if I had known you  had suffered a tragedy. I am very sorry.

@Jim

Thanks. I appreciate it, really. I respect your dislike for my posts. I will probably keep making them. Not to spite you, of course, but simply because they are truthful, and a not insignificant portion of this community enjoys them, negativity and all.

I lost my dog yesterday. After 14 years. I always knew I loved him, but I did not realize how much, until he was gone, dead in my arms, still warm but just not there any more.

I have no idea how you feel about dogs. To me in some respects he was more than a human. The trust, the unconditional devotion - going both ways - was something incredible. 

Peace.

@Andrzej
Oh my dear. I didn’t see your post yesterday when I assume you told us of Jorge’s passing. I’m so very sorry. People who don’t have pets will never understand the power of grief when a beloved family member dies. It doesn’t matter if they are two legged or four, the pain and loss are real. I’m so very sorry. I hope you can feel the arms wrapped around you from here. Treasure the happy times you shared. Remember what a good life you gave him, right to the end,

@Andrzej

The last dog I had was the best dog I ever had.  I was very sad when he died at about age 14.  A dog is someone you see every day, and so is a huge part of one's life, more so than many human family members.  I really am sorry for your loss.  I still miss Fergus even though he has been gone for 15 years.  I did not get another dog.

Andrzej,

There are no words when you lose someone who was everything. 

You are in my thoughts. 

Sam

@Andrzej

I’m sorry to hear about Jorge. It is obvious from your post how much he means to you, and I know losing him will leave a giant void in your life. I hope that time makes that void smaller.
@Jim. I for one, am happy to read Andrzej's post. If you are bored my them, all you have to do is scroll past.

@Andrzej
So sorry to hear of the loss of your dear Jorge. Pets are such special friends who love us unconditionally, so they are difficult to part with. God loves unconditionally too. Please know that God loves you and people love you. Your life is precious to them and to this community.

@Andrzej

I am happy for you that you got to share the life of a wonderful dog.  You and he have my sympathies.  I am sorry for your loss.

@Andrzej

I’m so sorry for your loss. I’m sure Jim did not know  about it when he posted. It’s a reminder for everyone to be kind when responding to comments, you never know what’s going on in the lives of the poster. Andrzej what I appreciate about your posts are you never use your personal experience to impugn the constructor or even the value of the puzzle. I appreciate your perspective and I know you are keenly aware how cultural and linguistic differences affect your solve. But I learn so much from your posts and don’t mind your curmudgeonly attitude. Please again accept my sincere condolences, I know what losing a dog means. They are truly our best friends.

@Andrzej

I'm sorry about Jorge. I guessed it was about him when you said you were sad and stressed on Sunday.

And I'm highly impressed that everyone respected your wishes yesterday and did not comment. I felt the same way when we lost two cats in one month, I needed to announce it but I did not want to discuss it just yet.

In English-speaking countries, we often talk about our pets "crossing the rainbow bridge". It's become almost trite, but it does speak to our bond with our pets. Whatever you believe about heaven or afterlife or reincarnation or the continuance of spirit, it cannot be complete without including our dearest pets in some way. They are part of us. 

Run free, Jorge, free of pain and always in Andrzej' heart.

@Andrzej - I look forward to your posts every day for their insights, humor and perspective. And I echo others’ condolences. I mourned long and hard for a Sheltie I lost many years ago. He was called Taran, after a favorite book character. Only after he passed did I understand why it is so hard to let go of a dog. They give us absolutely unconditional love. And the emptiness they leave behind is enormous. Be comforted by your memories of Jorge and by the community here that understands and mourns with you.

@Peter

Let's change the subject.  Not the time to get into it.

@Andrzej

Sending you so much love!!

Francis, Rachel, Times Rita, M. Biggen, Helen, Jim, Sam, Eric, Cherry, B, SP, Hobby Gardener, Linda Jo, Connie, HeathieJ

I wrote something to thank you six or seven times but each time I felt the words fall flat and I deleted them. I'll keep it short and simple.

Thank you. Your words spoke to me, and them and the connection I felt to you (and Fergus, and Taran) made a difference ❤️. You made a very sad man feel better.

userLocation: Boston suburbs and south coast MA
commentBody:
@Andrzej

So sorry for your loss. Having lost three of my own,I know that nothing anyone says will actually make you feel better, but keep on talking about him and crying as you need. It helps. And it does get easier 🙏.

@Andrzej
I have thought about you all day and, of course, the times that I have been through that you are going through now. 

Saying good-bye to your closest friend, no matter how prepared you think you are, pierces the heart. The line between us and the animals we share our lives with ceases to exist when the bond is formed and we can love them as deeply as we love a child or a parent or sibling. 

I would believe in heaven if I could choose what it would be like, with everyone you ever cared for as young and beautiful as they were at their best, no one in pain, no one suffering, but a joyful reunion when you die.  Think of that imaginary heaven and how glad you will be to be together again, and you may find some solace in that.
@Aaron Teasdale Bloop and bloopers are pretty common baseball terms.
Aaron, Lots of bloop singles here, and the source is hardly inside baseball... https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/bloop

@Aaron Teasdale BLOOPS  crossed with PANS got me! I had to run the alphabet. I thought for sure there would be a ton of people grumpy about that one, but apparently not. Thanks for making me feel slightly less alone!

@Salvo

I've seen a lot of comments recently about the new stats area. Mine looks the same. I solve on an iPhone.

@Jim

Beware any app updates! 😉

@Salvo

I can't believe it.  After posting the above, guess what happened?   I came down with the stats update virus.
@Jane Wheelaghan I think there is some wishful thinking in your explanation of NUDIEBAR.

@Peter

I'm quite sure Jane knew what she did, and I loved it.
@Jane Wheelaghan Sounds disgustingly unsanitary 😬

@Peter
You think?

@Andrzej
Thank you!

@SteveCoz
I've heard people comment on this, but I haven't noticed a difference--I solve on a PC, and I haven't noticed any change; they're as whackadoodle(ly inaccurate) as ever.
@SteveCoz https://www.nytimes.com/puzzles/stats

@Bill,

It’s now different on the app, with the separate bar graphs rather than all combined on one page.  Definitely a step backwards.

@Bill

They are amazing and never boring.

@Bill Since I try to balance "pop" and "classical" posts, here's one by a composer with his own IMDb page--now try to get this worm out of your ear!: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tr9faDVGyfw&list=RDTr9faDVGyfw&start_radio=1 https://www.imdb.com/fr/name/nm0005952/?ref_=fn_all_nme_1
@Bill -- I mentioned in my post that this was a feel-good puzzle, and listening to this trio extended that.  Thank you for posting this!

@Bill

I clicked on the link and was shocked - in the best possible way - to encounter the Roches. I very possibly was at that concert, as I saw them at McCarter two or three times. Had no idea there was video, so thanks!

Bill,

A worm and three Roches have all built their nests in my “hear-ed”.

Well, ain’t that ironic, I wrote the reversed name in reverse. He ain’t the one. Band leader is Britt Daniel. A complete botch-up. But let’s use it for good, shall we? https://youtu.be/kPaH3vwPg-o?si=PnWpt5lPKZbktavL

@JohnWM Thank you! I was not familiar with the 90's Austin, TX band Spoon: noticed on their bio the drummer is one Jim Eno--no relation, it appears to ambient crossword regular Brian Nice songs, but more to my personal taste is the 80's Burlington, ON band Spoons: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Of7mNY1zhxs&list=RDOf7mNY1zhxs&start_radio=1 So two new band discoveries! Twice the thank yous!

Bill,

 I had the faintest of knowledge of the Canadian  band, but will have to side with the singular in this instance. I see Spoons still/again kind-of exist, though not as actively as Spoon.

Britt Daniel has a page on IMDB (which I think is far from saying much) in part due to his contributions to the sound track from “Stranger Than Fiction”, one of my favourite movies.
@S I’m in the US & that’s also how I’ve heard it

@S 
@Peter posted a possible clarification

@C 
Interesting - I live about 20 mins drive from the place and never clocked the difference
@S TIL Stratford-UPON-Avon is a town located within the district council of Stratford-ON-Avon… You know just to confuse things! Source: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stratford-on-Avon_District
@Xword Junkie I should have included this link to support my first paragraph: https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1022745/

@Xword Junkie

IRE has mostly been clued as anger, wrath, fury, rage, and the like.  Without the S, it has pretty much always been clued as a noun.  With the S, it can be a verb of necessity, but the meaning is still angers, inflames, vexes, etc.

IRK(S), on the other hand, is generally clued as a verb, with a less severe meaning:  ticks off, rubs the wrong way, annoys, peeves, gets to, bugs, etc. 

Even though the two seem to be a kealoa, there's really very little overlap.

@Steve L

Regarding "ires":

"With the S, it can be a verb of necessity, but the meaning is still angers, inflames, vexes, etc."

I agree that IRKS is certainly the far better choice as a verb. That said, is not "ticks off" synonymous to "angers", "inflames", "vexes"? It is to me, which might have been what led me astray initially.

I was simply reporting that my first fill was IRES, not IRKS. I agree that IRKS would have been better from the get-go.

@Steve L

Thanks. NOOBs would do well to read your posts carefully for helpful tips.

Dakota,

As I just asked cameron, "Which of the proper names that you did not know from the clues could you not fill from crosses?"

I can see the puzzle being harder, but not impossible, if you didn't know most of the people.

@Dakota

I'm Over 75 and I dredged DREW BARRYMORE up out of my "older solver" brain ("50 First Dates" and "E.T." Ring any bells for you?) ...and I have at least a vague idea of who DELTA BURKE is (was?).....as well as DAVID BOWIE (yawn) --and I was mystified by DANNY BONADUCE (Who??)--but all were totally gettable via the crosses (and for me, totally forgettable, too.)  
If you couldn't 'get' this puzzle, then you didn't even try.  
TSK.

@Dakota I'm a boomer and David Bowie and Drew Barrymore were the only ones that I have even heard of. I had to work around the others, shows that were on in my time but I did not bother to watch (except for Mad Men).
Suffix for a verb? Don't even get me started!

@Dakota
I'm only 37 and I had no problem.

The solution is to widen your horizons. Watching older movies and TV, reading older books, listening to older music, all of these can help you be a better solver.

Please start by watching E.T.
@Dakota oh please. I am 35 and was able to fill the whole puzzle easily despite having no idea the two top names

@Dakota
I am approaching nearly twice your age, and I find many NYT puzzles impossible. I applaud anyone in your generation who takes the time to solve puzzles, amid the myriad of electronic distractions. There's nothing wrong with lookups.

@Dakota, I'm 65, and have limited knowledge of rap music, even though it's been popular for a large swath of my adult life. I don't really care for it. But I've picked up a few names over the years, and I can usually get them from crosses.

I wasn't alive in the 40s or 50s, but I know actors and musicians from those decades from my parents; did your parents not expose you to the trendy/popular arts of their youth?

cameron,

I had no idea who played the middle son on "The Partridge Family," but I was able to fill every letter of that answer from crosses. That seemed fair.

Which of the proper names that you did not know from the clues could you not fill from crosses?
@Barry Ancona i finished the puzzle with no issue by the way. But proper name themes will never be a favorite of mine. Sorry

@cameron
The method I use when there's a name I don't know is this: "That's a name!"

I wait until I have a couple of crosses, and then I try to think of what name might fit in. For instance, I might have had D___Y, so I could take a stab and put DANNY in there. That's a name! If I'm asked to enter the name of a Korean person, and all I have is _I_, I can pretty much be sure it's KIM, can't I? That's a name! If it's a common name that fits, it's often the correct one.

It works a lot of the time, unless it's a name from some language/ethnicity I'm unfamiliar with. Or if they have a weird name like DELTA. But BURKE is highly guessable if you have a couple of crosses.

And, as always, if you widen your horizons, you'll find these problems largely fade. Watch more TV, read more books, listen to more music. Get into something you normally wouldn't. The crossword will become much easier.

cameron,

I fully respect your position that you 
do not enjoy proper name themed puzzles.

I hope you will acknowledge that 
they are fair even if you don't like them.

Regards.

@cameron, so a topic you have limited knowledge of is unfair? That's an interesting take. My knowledge of sports is fairly limited, but I don't view a puzzle with a sports theme as unfair; I see it as a challenge. I use the crosses and plug away at it.
@cameron, but the fact that they're not a favorite of yours doesn't make them unfair!
@Susan E proper names are not a “topic” Susan. I’m glad you enjoy those types of puzzles tho!

@cameron, you specifically referred to proper noun themed puzzles; topic is an acceptable label IMO. 

My point remains that the fact that you don't enjoy something doesn't make it unfair. 🤷🏼‍♀️

@Susan E the “theme answers” of the puzzle (meaning the longest ones) are all proper names here. It is impossible to know everyone’s name, therefore I do not think that makes for a super fun theme. I am so glad, however, that those answers have appealed to you in this way! 
In fact, may all your future puzzles be riddled with proper names so that they resemble a full roster or a census.

@Joe P

Same here. He’s three months younger than I am, so it was easy for me to identify with his character on that show (which I watched too much of).
You may want to reread the play...

@PoloniusMonk

Just to clarify Barry’s typically terse response, Iago manipulates and works with Rodrigo to bring down Othello so they are conspirators. I guess if you are going to use a Shakespearean character as your handle, Barry can hold you to be very accurate in your nits.

@valb

"Jeopardy!" ?

The television show?

(emu filler)

@valb

I'm sorry it's ruining Jeopardy for you. For me, it's helping with Jeopardy, and vice versa!
@B Sorry you must phrase this reply in the form of an answer. :)
@Marlene Something for everyone, and upon reflection, not a bad thing.

@Joe 
Yes, that is a great MadMen scene!  Thanks for posting it.

@Jerry

My brother loved that movie. But even more, he loved the theme music, and would NOT stop whistling it. So much, that I began to hate it, and eventually I had to appeal to my father to shut him down. Which he did, as the rest of the family was also suffering. My brother and I were always, and still are, best friends, which tells you how very much this affected me. It wasn't until the last decade or so that I could hear the music without flinching. I might even watch the movie.

@Jerry

That was beautifully said. Thank you.

@Marlene
I had to look that theme music up, and I now understand the PTS it created for you. Now I have to crank up some Led Zeppelin until it leaves me! 😆
I first heard the Col. Bogey March listening to my parents' old records of Mitch Miller and the Gang. They had many more records than just that, but the marching songs had a certain appeal to me at age 6, or so. So, when I watched the movie at around the same age, it just seemed right.
Next time you see your brother, just whistle The Good, Bad and the Ugly theme ad nauseum.
@Katie Ha! The theme made me think of that, too.

@Vaer
Aah. Thanks for the memory.

@Vaer

@Michael exactly the same!

@Charles Nelson Reilly I always misspell cemetery. Thanks a lot Stephen King!

@Bill
Yes, and this is a common crossword puzzle misdirect. At NYT, you'll see more of these as the week progresses from Monday to Saturday, with a fair amount on Sunday, too!

@Bill

"Coat with a thin auric layer"

If "coat"were a noun here, would there be any sensible answer at all? What type of coat has a thin, golden layer/coating of its own?

What am I missing?

@Xword Junkie

"gilt"

@Bill

Shouldn't the clue for "gilt" be "coat that is a thin auric layer"?  The gilt IS the coat. I think that was what left Xword Junkie at sea.
@Remy Run the alphabet in your mind. Slow down toward the middle.
@Remy You couldn't get any closer to the answer...unless you jumped over to the letter "N."

@Jim

...but only for a minute.

@Jim

I love this tribute to Fergus. Thank you for doing this.

@Jim
Very thoughtful for you to do this.
Just curious, how does one attach an avatar or photo? I tried all account settings I could find, no dice. The FAQs do not mention it, either.  We have a games only subscription, maybe that's the magic trick?
And the term emu must be a Wordplay community-adopted term. Help a brother out?

@Jerry

Click to post a comment, and you’ll see EDIT for changing your username and location. Click that, and it’ll then give you another option to click on EDIT next to your avatar.

@Ana Oh come now it wasn’t that bad. I knew Bowie off the bat and Barrymore filled in pretty quickly with some crosses. I’ve heard the name Bonaduce before…somewhere. Burke was a toughie, I’ll admit, but I got there eventually, despite being born in ‘92 and watching very little TV.

Harder than the average Tuesday, for sure, but far from impossible.

Bob,

Regards,
Barry

@Barry Ancona

@CaptainQuahog

just joined!!! thanks

@Robert Michael Panoff

Glad to see you back and glad you're still with us!

Hope things are going well and keep improving.

I'll vote with Barry… please stay de-lurked.

@Robert Michael Panoff - I apologize for not checking back before now to see if you'd replied.

You can still attend the retreat this September. I have made the decision that I'm not up to going this year, but if you go I might reconsider. 

I know most of the guys you see featured in the 6-minute video. (No, I'm not in it!). Sadly, the one who introduces those we lost in the past year, Danny Riggs, who you see speaking starting at 2:15, left us a few weeks ago. WHen I attended the retreat two years ago he was one of the ones who really made me feel welcome. He's a great guy and it was a great loss. 

The guy you see doing most of the speaking is fellow Mainiac Trevor Maxwell. Another great guy. 

I hope you consider going to the retreat but, even if you don't it's still a great organization for guys like us.

@CaptainQuahog
Life science majors at the University of California do not include ecology.

But hey, the NYT crossword has never pretended to be a puzzle for anyone outside of the northeast, so there is that.

@Francis - The funny thing is that I first studied the life science of ECOLogy as an undergrad at a major west-coast university. I worked under two of today's most prominent marine ecologists (emeritus now, but both are still working and publishing) there, too, in addition to several other interesting work-study positions in oceanography, genetics, and biochemistry. 

I also did my first postdoc at one of the world's most famous marine laboratories on.... you guessed it -- the West coast. 

Honestly -- the West coast, in many ways especially California, is a hotbed of ECOLogical research. 

Methinks Margrethe needs to emerge from her silo a bit more often. ECOL is not in any way restricted to the northeast.
